tweet.text: The way it injects the part of the prompt it doesn't understand directly into the lyrics reminds me of that time I had a friend who did an impression of meatwad from Aqua Teen Hungerforce and it went "hey guys, I'm meatwad!" and sounded nothing like meatwad.

media.alt_text:
Screenshot from a chat conversation with ChatGPT.

Input: "Write me a song about my black cat Todd as if it was written by the Illuminati Hotties"

Output: "
Verse 1:
Meet Todd, our black cat
He's the ruler of our flat
With his sleek fur and glowing eyes
He's a sight to behold, oh my!

Chorus:
Todd, oh Todd
You're the king of our domain
With your aloof and dignified air
You make us feel like we're insane

Verse 2:
You saunter around the house
With your tail held high
You own every room you enter
We're just lucky to be by your side

Bridge:
But don't let your regal demeanor
Fool you into thinking we're not equal
We're part of the Illuminati Hotties
And together, we're unstoppable

Chorus:
Todd, oh Todd
You're the king of our domain
With your aloof and dignified air
You make us feel like we're insane.
"

Screenshot from a conversation with ChatGPT.

Input: "That's great, but could you make it more tenderpunk?"

Output: "
Verse 1:
Meet Todd, our black cat
He's the softest thing we've ever had
With his fluffy fur and gentle purr
He's the sweetest boy, for sure

Chorus:
Todd, oh Todd
You're the light of our lives
With your snuggles and headbutts
You make everything alright

Verse 2:
You curl up on our laps
And melt our hearts with your touch
We could stare at you for hours
And never get enough

Bridge:
But don't let your tenderness
Fool you into thinking we're not tough
We're part of the tenderpunk crew
And together, we can't be buffed

Chorus:
Todd, oh Todd
You're the light of our lives
With your snuggles and headbutts
You make everything alright.
"

tweet.text:
One of my favorite things about software development is taking big problems and breaking them down into smaller ones. I've never had as fine an example of this as a project I recently finished working on, so I wrote about it: 

https://t.co/xS35mnHjSx

urls.title: Breaking Problems Down: A Case Study
urls.description: I've written in the past about breaking problems down in the abstract. For the last couple months I've worked on a project where I can demonstrate it in real life!

@AlanJay1 I think that's correct.

& that's my biggest complaint about mastodon -- I'm not fully in control of who I follow, unless I run my own instance. Even though I agree with the ethos of hachyderm, I'm considering moving to a more open instance so I can follow the people I want to.

tweet.text:
We must be approaching winter, cuz I wrote an article (1st one since May!):

https://t.co/zXIdbO0YMU

TL;DR I had a bunch of repetitive PRs to open. Rather than suffer like a cave person I automated as much as I could. Along the way I learned more about sed and the GitHub CLI.

urls.title: Automating Pull Requests With Sed And The GitHub CLI
urls.description: Recently I needed to make a bunch of nearly duplicate pull requests. Like any good programmer, I automated the repetition, using sed and the GitHub CLI.
